results.title: A Messy Table, a Map of the World
results.abstract: Dutch still life paintings like this one do more than depict luxurious objects. They narrate history on a global scale.

results.title: Susan Jaffe to Be Next Artistic Director at American Ballet Theater
results.abstract: A former star ballerina with the company, Jaffe will assume the reins after the 30-year tenure of Kevin McKenzie.

results.abstract: Ahead of this week’s final round, a writer and photographer went backstage for this state-versus-state competition based on Eurovision. The singers get it. Does America?

results.title: Review: Igor Levit Arrives at the Philharmonic, at Last
results.abstract: Levit, one of the world’s eminent pianists, appeared with the orchestra at Carnegie Hall eight years after making his New York debut.

multimedia.caption: The pianist Igor Levit made his New York Philharmonic debut at Carnegie Hall on Friday.
The pianist Igor Levit made his New York Philharmonic debut at Carnegie Hall on Friday.
The pianist Igor Levit made his New York Philharmonic debut at Carnegie Hall on Friday.

results.title: Review: ‘Wedding Band,’ a Searing Look at Miscegenation Nation
results.abstract: Alice Childress’s 1962 play about interracial love and hate gets its first major New York revival in 50 years.

multimedia.caption: Brittany Bradford, left, and Thomas Sadoski in the Theater for a New Audience production of the play “Wedding Band.”
Brittany Bradford, left, and Thomas Sadoski in the Theater for a New Audience production of the play “Wedding Band.”

results.title: Warhol’s $200 Million ‘Marilyn’ Could Test Art Market’s Health
results.abstract: The painting is poised to wrest the auction high for an American artwork from Jean-Michel Basquiat.
results.byline: By Robin Pogrebin and Scott Reyburn

multimedia.caption: A viewer with Andy Warhol’s “Shot Sage Blue Marilyn” (1964) at Christie’s New York, which will be offered Monday night. The sale, the first of the spring auctions, could be a bellwether of the market’s health.

A viewer with Andy Warhol’s “Shot Sage Blue Marilyn” (1964) at Christie’s New York, which will be offered Monday night. The sale, the first of the spring auctions, could be a bellwether of the market’s health.

results.title: Ncuti Gatwa Is the New Doctor on ‘Doctor Who’
results.abstract: Mr. Gatwa, a star of the Netflix series “Sex Education,” will be the first Black man to play the lead character in the enduring BBC science fiction franchise.

multimedia.caption: Ncuti Gatwa will be the 14th actor and the first Black man to portray the Doctor on “Doctor Who.”
Ncuti Gatwa will be the 14th actor and the first Black man to portray the Doctor on “Doctor Who.”
Ncuti Gatwa will be the 14th actor and the first Black man to portray the Doctor on “Doctor Who.”

results.title: Madonna and Beeple Collaborate on NFT Project
results.abstract: The pop singer spent the last year working with the digital artist on a video series about motherhood. Proceeds will benefit three nonprofits.

multimedia.caption: A still from Madonna and Beeple’s NFT artwork “Mother of Creation” (2022), part of a video triptych they created.
A still from Madonna and Beeple’s NFT artwork “Mother of Creation” (2022), part of a video triptych they created.

results.title: ‘A Strange Loop’ Nominated for 11 Tonys as Broadway Lauds Comeback
results.abstract: “The Lehman Trilogy,” as well as revivals of “Company” and “For Colored Girls,” led in their respective categories as the industry tries to recover from the long pandemic shutdown.

multimedia.caption: “A Strange Loop” was nominated for 11 Tony Awards, including best new musical. One of the nods went to its star, Jaquel Spivey, who plays Usher, a Broadway usher who is trying to write a show.
“A Strange Loop” was nominated for 11 Tony Awards, including best new musical. One of the nods went to its star, Jaquel Spivey, who plays Usher, a Broadway usher who is trying to write a show.

results.title: In Elif Batuman’s ‘Either/Or,’ a Witty and Perceptive Young Woman Returns
results.abstract: Batuman’s follow-up to “The Idiot” follows the same character into her second year at Harvard.

results.title: Review: Handel’s ‘Serse,’ With Yuks and Exquisite Playing
results.abstract: The English Concert’s performance at Carnegie Hall showed off the ensemble’s elastic responsiveness.

results.title: How Elizabeth Olsen Came Into Her Powers
results.abstract: The actress started as an indie darling and never expected to become a Marvel linchpin as Wanda Maximoff. But she’s now so invested in the role, she’s open to a solo film.

results.title: Paula Vogel on ‘How I Learned to Drive’ nominations: ‘I’m just thrilled.’
results.abstract: Twenty-five years after it was a hit Off Broadway, the playwright’s Pulitzer Prize-winning work debuted on Broadway this season.

multimedia.caption: Paula Vogel in 2017. Her 1997 play “How I Learned to Drive,” which won the Pulitzer Prize, arrived on Broadway this spring with its orginal leads, Mary-Louise Parker and David Morse.

results.title: The Perfect Daughter Vanished on Prom Night. The Question Is: Why?
results.abstract: In Casey McQuiston’s Y.A. debut, “I Kissed Shara Wheeler,” a queer teenage rebel is on the hunt to find her school’s missing golden girl, who, it turns out, is hiding a few secrets.

results.title: There were Tony snubs and surprises, as always.
results.abstract: Several stars, including Daniel Craig and Sarah Jessica Parker, were not nominated for their performances, while “Paradise Square” became one of the season’s most-nominated shows.
results.byline: By Michael Paulson and Scott Heller

results.title: Future Earns an Eighth No. 1 Album With ‘I Never Liked You’
results.abstract: The Atlanta rapper’s latest release had the largest numbers of the year so far, but big new LPs from Bad Bunny and Jack Harlow will register on next week’s chart.

multimedia.caption: “I Never Liked You” is the eighth chart-topping album by Future. The album had the equivalent of 222,000 sales in the United States, more than any release this year.

results.title: A Woman Alone in Oman: Three Weeks Along the Arabian Coast
results.abstract: In December, a photographer set off on a 2,600-mile road trip, traveling from the Yemeni border to the Strait of Hormuz. Here’s what she saw.

multimedia.caption: Dromedaries graze in the marsh where fresh water from Wadi Ashawq meets the Arabian Sea.

results.title: Review: ‘Falling Out of Time’ Gives Song to a Father’s Grief
results.abstract: Osvaldo Golijov’s evening-length work, based on the book by David Grossman about his son, had its New York premiere at Zankel Hall.

multimedia.caption: Members of the Silkroad Ensemble — and the vocalists, from left, Yoni Rechter, Nora Fischer and Biella Da Costa — in the New York premiere of Osvaldo Golijov's “Falling Out of Time” at Zankel Hall on Friday.

results.title: Ric Parnell, Real Drummer in a Famous Fake Band, Dies at 70
results.abstract: The central characters in the mockumentary “This Is Spinal Tap” were comic actors, but Mr. Parnell was an actual professional musician.

multimedia.caption: Ric Parnell performing with Spinal Tap in Minneapolis in 1992. His character, Mick Shrimpton, died near the end of the movie “This Is Spinal Tap,” released in 1984; when the band later went on tour, he was said to be Mick’s twin brother, Rick.

Ric Parnell performing with Spinal Tap in Minneapolis in 1992. His character, Mick Shrimpton, died near the end of the movie “This Is Spinal Tap,” released in 1984; when the band later went on tour, he was said to be Mick’s twin brother, Rick.
